bibl.title: Letter from Jefferson Randolph Kean to Albert E. Truby, October 2, [1941]

div1.p: Kean informs Hench that Truby's book will be published by the S.G.O. He also discusses various people who were or were not in Cuba during the yellow fever experiments.

div1.head: Letter from Jefferson Randolph Kean to Albert E. Truby, October 2, [1941]
div1.opener:
2804 N St. N.W.
Washington D.C.
Oct. 2nd
My dear Truby
div1.p:
I have just finished your fine memoir
and am going to get it off in express this aft.
I considered the suggestive of asking the S.G.O
to get it off in a frank and by air, but it is
difficult for me to contact them and get the
package to them. My colored boy has gone off
and I have no one to send it by. But they tell
me that you will get it in 4 days. I put up to
Ireland your suggestion to let Mrs Stark read it
first but he turned thumbs down on that proposal
with great emphasis, in which I agree with him.
I do not think she can shed any light on the subject
and if she made suggestions they might be embar-
rassing to reject, if not useful. My diary shows that
they left Cuba on Sept. 3, 1900 on the Rollius
with Gen. Lee and did not return until Oct. 27
Reed was amused by Stark but I do not think
he could have confided in him to any extent, as
Alex was a great talker and often an indiscrete
one and as you see he was not there during the
critical period and I cannot recall any
contribution that he made. Mrs Stark shone in
the Epidemic in June, when Major Edwards died
She took his two children into her family and
cared for them with her own until Mrs. Edwards re
covered.
AC
T
2
my suggestions are, as you will see, all in
small matters. Sternberg was never a Major General
The Bureau chief in his day were Brigadiers.
Gen O'Reilly was always proud of the fact that he
was the first Medical Officer to become a Major
General. Also O'Reilly did not immediately follow
him. Old man Forward who had a fine Civil
War record was about to retire as a Colonel and
they made him Surgeon General for 3 months & 10
days so that he could retire as a Brigadier.
I would suggest that you do not speak of the
Cubans as the “natives”. They are a proud and
sensitive people and there is a sort-of off-color
suggestion about the term. I note you say the
Post Hospital was at the south western corner of
Columbia Bks. Should it not be south-eastern?
Quemados was certainly so-east of it. I wish I
could remember Dr. Wertenbakers given name
If I can find it I will pass it on. I will be
glad to see what Pinto has to say. I have
asked Dr Hench to pass in to you several
papers of interest that I came across in
looking over my files for him. One bears on
the question when Gorgas began his mosquito
work. I do not think he began until March.
He did not get a city ordinance imposing fines for
breeding mosquitoes until some time in April.
And Dr. L.O. Howard letter quotes one of Reeds
in which he speaks of G.O. no. 6 Div. of Cuba
I think that Ireland has written you that the S.G.O. has agreed
to publish your Memoir as a bulletin in book form. That was a fine
catch, your 27 pound salmon - Love to Mrs Truby if she is with
you.
